authors: EMMANUEL P LEAÑO, ALFREDO J ANCENO, SANDHYA BABEL
description: Palm oil production is a major agro-industrial activity in Southeast Asia and is a major source of inland water pollution in Southern Thailand. The resulting palm oil mill effluent (POME) releases significant quantities of greenhouse gases into the environment when left in wastewater lagoons. If POME is used to produce methane, its combustion will also end up in greenhouse gases. Hydrogen production was hence sought since POME is rich in carbohydrates (ie lignocellulose), suspended solids, and oil. There are a number of studies dealing with hydrogen production from organics-rich wastewaters, through dark fermentation. However, studies on POME pretreatment as to increase bioavailability is limited. Ultrasonication is known to enhance reaction rates in several bioprocesses by increasing the surface area of reactants via the mechanisms of cavitation and acoustic streaming. When applied to tenacious biomass, the resulting disintegration releases soluble substrates. Increased surface area and dissolution results in increased accessibility to biocatalysts such as enzymes and microorganisms. We therefore investigated the impact of ultrasonication on hydrogen yield from POME under a hypothesis that the pretreatment strategy will increase its bioavailability to the target microflora.

description: This study aims to evaluate the effectiveness of Musa spp. ABB cv. description: The purpose of this study was to test the effect of Pseudomonas psychrophila, isolated from the roots of metallophyte Pityrogramma calomelanos (L.) Link collected from the Song Tho abandon Pb mine, Thailand, on Pb accumulation of Acacia mangium Willd. and Eucalyptus camaldulensis Dehnh. grown in lead (Pb) solution. These plants were inoculated by pruned-root dip method. Further, inoculated plant and un-inoculated plants were treated in 30 mg/L of Pb as Pb (CH3COO) 2‧ 3H2O and without Pb served as control for 15 days. Pb concentrations in the roots were determined by a flame atomic absorption spectrophotometer (FAAS) after acid digestion. The results showed that the background Pb concentration in the roots grown in the 25% modified Hoagland’s nutrient solution without Pb showed no significant difference (p> 0.05) ranging from 10-89 mg/kg. In the presence of 30 mg/L Pb, there were no significant changes in Pb contents in roots caused by inoculations. However, A. mangium inoculation showed increase trend in Pb concentration in the roots (6,829±697 mg/kg) compared to non-inoculation (6,242±272 mg/kg). While, E. camaldulensis inoculation showed decreased trend in Pb content (3,763±592 mg/kg) compared to non-inoculation (4,233±264 mg/kg). These results suggest that P. psychrophila seemed to be effective in promoting the phytoremediation potential of A. mangium, however, it was not useful for Pb phytoremediation of E. camaldulensis.

authors: Xaysackda Vilaysouk, Sandhya Babel
description: Greenhouse gas (GHG) emission from municipal solid waste (MSW) management contribute to 3% of GHG globally. GHG from treatment and disposal of MSW is of significant concern. Social-economic activities and seasonal variation are strongly correlated with the composition and the amount of MSW. Luangprabang (LPB), a tourist city, located in north of Lao PDR, is facing challenges due to lack of proper MSW management. This study aims to estimate GHG emission from landfill in LPB, considering the amount and characteristic of MSW at disposal year. International Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) 2006 model is used in this study. Result from this study indicates that from 57.75 Gg/year of MSW disposed on landfill, of which 83% is biodegradable material (food waste, garden waste, paper and textile), 2.42 Gg CH4 as GHG is produced. As Lao PDR has agriculture oriented economy, and as most waste is biodegradable, composting can be adopted. This can reduce amount of MSW disposed on landfill and give the compost and also reduce amount of GHG emission.
tittle: Estimation of Greenhouse Gas Emission from Landfill in Luangprabang, Lao PDR

description: Municipal solid waste (MSW) disposal is the most popular method for MSW in least developed countries together with developing countries as this is cheap and requires less professional skills.
